text: Saturn swims against the stars, its rings slicing the nig DIONE, a pale moon, looms in the foreground.
A battleship crosses the moon’s disk. On its hull: the na HIGHLINE - and the symbol of a red hawk.

CAPTAIN CONRAD VANCE of the Offworld Marine Corps prepare for combat. He is a rugged man of 40, calm and focused. I his massive ARMORED SPACE SUIT he looks superhuman: a hal ton war machine. His rifle is big as a cannon. Technicians swarm around him, checking systems. Nearby, more technicians tend to ELEVEN OTHER MARINES: el soldiers in their late 20s and early 30s. Vance is first on his feet. He steps free of his prep sta and walks the line, inspecting his men. Motors hum as he walks. His footfalls shake the deck. One of Vance's men catches his eye - MOX, a seasoned sold
What do you think, Cap? Vance shrugs - a massive movement of armored shoulders.
The ammo load is armor-piercing, so whatever we're fighting, it's big.

That's right. Silence in the room. The Marines turn to the man who stan on a raised deck above them: their commander, COLONEL COB Coburn wears an ordinary uniform and a headset. He frowns concentration, listening and talking at once.
The Hegemony has heavy tanks advancing on the Dione Colony.
The Colony has anti-ship guns. How did they land tanks?
They dropped 'em weeks ago on the far side of the moon. They crawled all the way around, right under the radar.
What crawled all the way around?
Four D-Class tanks. And a mystery target. Something bigger.
Bigger than a D-Class?
Something new. Target's designated “Colossus”. We've got destroyers inbound, but they’re six hours away. Right now you’re all we have. The Marines become grim. This is a desperate action.

Six thousand people live and work in the Dalton Mining Colony. Maybe they’1l be rotting in prison ships tonight. Maybe they'll be free. You decide it now. Lock in. The Marines step into metal drop capsules. The capsules c and sink into their launch tubes.

The DIONE COLONY, an industrial city, sits rooted to the rock. The red hawk symbol is painted on its walls. Around the city, the mines lie silent: digging machines abandoned in their trenches. MISSILES swarm over the horizon toward the colony. The colony’s GUNS blast some from the sky. Other missiles detonate against the city walls. A digging machine EXPLODES in a weird airless fireball. Smoke clears. Across the valley, four D-CLASS TANKS clim over the ridgeline. They are three stories high, painted the blue interlocking circles of the Hegemony. The colony goes turtle: withdrawing its towers, it closes and hunkers down against the rock.
The Battleship's guns begin to fire in a cycle of terribl violence: pounding at their targets on the moon below. Twelve DROP-CAPSULES launch. Rocket toward the surface of Dione.

The battleship’s bombardment hammers the tanks. Near-miss and hits. Their armor is damaged but withstands the assau The tanks launch flares and interceptor missiles. A drop-capsule rockets down and shatters, revealing Vance full armor. He vaults from the impact crater - as a missi explodes where he just landed. Other drop capsules hurtle down, OTHER MARINES emerge. Th take cover in rocky terrain chaotic with explosions. ATHENA’S VOICE All troops down safe.

Marines! Give me a battle line, twenty meter spacing. Athena. Tactical. The electronic voice of his armor's battle computer answe him - feminine, calming. ATHENA’S VOICE Tactical. Vance’s visor lights up, painting the terrain around him data: enemies, friendlies, ranges and velocities. Each Marine is tagged in Vance's display with his name an status. Vance watches his men move into a battle line. ATHENA’S VOICE Four D-Class tanks incoming. Target “Colossus” out of range.  The four tanks loom closer. Behind them, Vance’s visor display indicates the Colossus, hidden behind the ridge.

Advance on me. Fire as you go. Vance moves toward the D-Class Tank at a run through the broken terrain. The other Marines join in seconds later, their rifles blazing. ATHENA’S VOICE Incoming fire. From the tanks, energy beams flash toward the Marines. Va cartwheels off the ground, JUMP-JETS flaring from his boo He arcs through space, firing all the while. Behind him Marines take evasive action on their jets.
We're not breaching the armor. Let's get close and do some demolition. ATHENA’S VOICE Fatality. Sergeant Holder. Vance charges a tank. Enemy fire rakes the ground around
Onscreen, Colonel Coburn watches the battle unfold below. A fatality marker throbs where Sergeant Holder fell. The eleven remaining Marines charge toward the enemy.

Vance reaches a tank: gets in under its guns and keeps go right between its gnashing treads and under its armored b From a pod on his thigh he pulls a series of powerful min Plants them on the belly of the tank.

Athena. Detonate on my mark. On the underside of the tank, belly hatches open. ARMED TROOPERS drop out. Their gunfire ricochets off his armor. Vance hurls a mine into an open hatch. Fires his jump-jet Cannonballs through the troopers into the clear.

Now! Behind him the tank EXPLODES spectacularly. Vance scans the battlefield - two of the D-Class Tanks bu furiously. Marines concentrate fire on the other two. ATHENA’S VOICE Fatality. Lieutenant Carver. Vance looks up, and gapes in awe. The COLOSSUS climbs ove the ridge: a tank twice as big as the D-Class machines. A fortress on the move.
I see the Colossus. It’s a monster.

We are hitting it now. A barrage of shells from the orbiting Battleship. Explosi march across the lunar surface and pound the Colossus. When the smoke clears, the Colossus is battered but intac still coming. Its mammoth guns rise to point toward the stars.
Heads up, Command! Colossus is returning fire... A thunderous concussion shakes the ground. Flames leap as Tank's heavy guns all fire at once.
Gunfire from the Colossus far below tears into the Battleship, triggering a chain of EXPLOSIONS.
Colonel Coburn, shaken badly, watches damage reports stre in from the Battleship’s burning sections.
Marines. We are hit. Highline is disengaging.
The Battleship veers away from Dione.

All four of the D-Class Tanks are burning hulks. Marines emerge from the smoking wreckage to advance on the Coloss Vance watches in horror as the mighty guns of the Colossu lower to engage in the surface battle.

Rapid advance! Move! Move! The battle line breaks into a run: the Marines sprint tow the Colossus, rifles flashing... The HEAVY GUNS of the Colossus open fire. The Marines tak evasive action - but one by one soldiers are BLASTED into oblivion. ATHENA’S VOICE Fatality. Sergeant Markhart. Fatality. Sergeant Chan. Casualty. Lieutenant Drake. Vance roars in rage.
Cover! Take cover! The Marines dive for shelter as the guns shake the earth.

(under his breath) Too many. Too many. He stares at the Colossus, scanning the giant war machine with telescopic vision. His gaze settles on the anti-personnel gun turrets that protrude like steel barrels from the tank's hull.

McGrath! Get to Drake. Run a med- check. Everybody else, fire from cover on my order. Target the sensors. Eyes and ears. I want that monster blind. Ready... (gathers himself, poised to sprint) Fire! Vance explodes from cover, racing toward the Colossus. A him, the Marines blast away at the Colossus's sensors wit precision rifle fire. Vance is half running and half flying, his jump-jets blaz The Colossus pounds the battlefield with haphazard firepo but Vance weaves and leaps and the gunfire doesn’t touch He gets in past the guns. Leaps onto the Colossus. Clings magnetically beside a gun turret. A plasma torch extends from his forearm. He aims at the s where the turret meets the hull and lights up. Blinding light from the contact point. His visor darkens. White-hot liquid metal gouts down the side of the tank. He plants his feet, wraps his arms around the gun and hea The motors of his battle-suit WHINE. ATHENA’S VOICE Warning. Critical strain.
(through clenched teeth) Override! With a SCREECH, the entire turret tears out of the tank. GUNNER spins to the rock below. A BLAST of escaping air. Vance swings into the hole.
Vance bulls down a passageway. He barely fits. The should of his armored suit scrape the walls. His visor’s heads-up display streams with data as ATHENA the inside of the tank.
Hold your fire. I’m inside the Colossus.

Inside?! A TANK CREWMAN rakes Vance with bullets that bounce off h armor. Vance blows him away with a single shot. Vance reaches a ladder-well leading upward. He starts up and his shoulders CLANG against the well rim. He doesn’t Vance heaves. The ladder rungs bend under his hands. Wit shriek of metal, the walls of the ladder-well give way.

The COMMAND CREW does damage control: drivers wrestle wit controls...gunnery officers search for targets. They wear light vacuum suits. Behind them, the ladder-well emerges from the deck plates A ROAR. The bridge is shaken by an unseen force. Vance BLASTS out of the ladder-well on his jets, SMASHES the ceiling. Lands on his feet in a shower of scrap metal The deck crew spins in alarm. Two crewmen pull pistols an fire. Bullets ricochet wildly. Vance’s rifle comes up.

An explosion blows out the Colossus’s command bridge. Jet flame billow into space. The Colossus goes dark. Churns to a stop. A hailstorm of shrapnel pelts the battlefield. Vance lands on his feet in the dust - armor dark with soo

The Marines gather again in their ready room. They are transformed: armor pitted and blackened, faces smeared wi sweat and blood. Only seven men remain. Technicians lift their helmets off, open up their armor. men are wounded: medics rush to help them. The Marines gather around Vance, slap his shoulders in gr celebration: they are mindful of their losses.
This was all you, Cap.
This was the fighting two-ten, best platoon in the Corps.
But the big kill was yours.
The kill belongs to the men we lost. When we get inside the Colony, we drink to them.
We won't be seeing the inside of Dione Colony. The men turn. Coburn stands above them on his command dec
We lift as soon as our casualties are aboard. The Marines murmur in protest.
Back to Mars already?
Earth. Special orders. Sudden silence.
What’s it about, sir?
I don't know. Captain Vance has been called home. We’re just along for the ride. The men’s eyes turn to Vance in surprise.

(to all the men) I wish I could grant you some shore leave. You've earned it. But I have orders. (points at Vance) You. In my stateroom. INT. BATTLESHIP HIGHLINE (IN FLIGHT) - COBURN’S STATEROOM A luxurious cabin by spacefaring standards but still cram Colonel Coburn sits reading an electronic slate. The engines rumble. Saturn’s rings slide past the porthol Vance enters in regular uniform, hair damp. He looks wary  10.

Vance, you've done more combat tours than any man in the division. I've done all I can to keep you where you want to be. But it looks like I'm losing you. (reads slate) “Transport Captain Conrad Vance to Earth ASAP. Run silent. Avoid hazard of combat. Vance to report on arrival to the State Science Agency for special duty.” Vance looks stunned. This makes no sense to him.
The SSA?
What it says. A battleship diverted to take one man home!
What does the Science Agency want with a Marine? Do they run combat ops?
Who knows what they do? But the Secretary of Defense signed the order himself. It’s for real.
I'm a soldier, not a lab rat. I'd like to protest the order.

Not under radio silence. Two weeks to Earth. Nothing to do ‘til then but rest up. Your orders. (he hands Vance the slate) Maybe it's time you got out of the field. You ought to have my job by now. Hell, you ought to be senior to me. How long can you keep refusing promotions?
I don't know. I'll stay in armor as long as they let me. (he laughs) Maybe that's what the Science guys want. To have my head examined.  11.
Vance and the other Marines lie in their bunks watching v on electronic slates as light as magazines. One soldier d off in front of a news broadcast:

The Allied States and the Hegemony broke off arms-control talks after weeks of deadlock. Stockpiles of fusion and gravity weapons continue to grow. Another soldier munches bright blue chips from a bag and watches a different channel:
Prices rose again as the population outgrew the food supply for the sixth year running... And a third soldier watches a video letter from home.
...somebody tapped into the Baxters' water pipes! At these prices I guess you can't be surprised. But imagine, stealing water! Vance watches a broadcast with particular interest:

+..-more than half of the federal budget is now classified. Despite popular outcry against this secret spending, the so-called "black funds" continue to grow. Five bunks are empty. Folded flags commemorate the dead.

The scarred Battleship passes an Allied States defensive space station: a huge manned satellite bristling with gun The satellite SCANS the Battleship with a laser beam as i passes. Earth shines below, half in light and half in shadow. On planet's night side, cities shine in the darkness: far la than today's cities, and connected by arteries of light.  12. The Battleship descends toward the eastern seaboard of No America - where dawn is fast approaching.

A vast landing ground surrounds the spaceport terminal. Military spacecraft lie at harbor. The distant towers of Washington shine in the sunrise. The Battleship Highline settles into a landing bay. A gan tube extends from the spaceport to the battleship.
Vance debarks alone, in dress uniform: his chest crowded medals. Walks the long transparent tube toward the termin His men watch him go, dressed in common fatigues.
Vance emerges from the gangway into a busy concourse. An officer in a military uniform stands waiting: JOHN RANDALL, 50, a good-natured bear of a man with a barrel c and a crew cut.
Captain Vance. (they exchange salutes, shake hands) Major John Randall. Department of Defense. Welcome home.
Vance and Randall walk together.
It's an honor to meet you, Captain. I know what you did on Dione. He shakes his head, speechless. Vance nods his thanks.
I'm here to make the handoff to your new command.
Who’s my C.O. now?  13. Randall's forehead wrinkles in perplexity.
The lawyers are looking at that. The whole arrangement's unusual. Technically, it looks like your c.0O. is Jarod Marbeck. Director of the State Science Agency.
(amazed) The Director of the SSA. And what does he want with me?
(shrugging) Secretary of Defense signed your orders. He didn’t tell me why.
Speak of the devil. He nods over Randall’s shoulder at...
The news. A pretty ANCHORWOMAN speaks. In an inset image, SECRETARY OF DEFENSE gives a press conference.

Secretary of Defense Gideon Dain today announced the end of hostilities over the Dalton Colony on Dione. The image cuts to the press conference. DEFENSE SECRETARY GIDEON DAIN speaks: a chiseled man with salt-and-pepper h and the brick-solid build of a career soldier.
Today the Hegemony surrendered its claim to our mining colonies on Dione, after last month’s defensive action by the Offworld Marines. Vance grins in satisfaction.
The action was exemplary. Our losses, acceptable... Vance’s smile fades.  14.
...and the Dalton Colonists remain free people. The news cuts to a piece on overpopulation.

Nobody minds losing some soldiers, as long we win. I was in the Offworld Corps myself. Seventeenth Division, Mercury terminator. (Randall hikes up his trouser leg. His right leg is a high-tech prosthetic.) Then I tangled with a neutron gun and landed me a desk job. Vance gives the artificial leg an expert glance.
That's a good leg. I have friends with that leg.

Vance and Randall exit the spaceport’s secure zone throug humming gauntlet of sensors and scanning beams. Beyond the barriers, a SCIENTIST waits: Vance’s age, athletically built. He wears a long black coat, styled li lab coat, and a black skullcap. His face shows no feeling
You must be...
Rune Banneker, Scientist.
(extending a hand) Captain Conrad Vance.
(ignoring the hand) Yes. Come with me. Banneker turns to leave. Randall scowls in indignation.
That's a war hero you're talking to. You take care of our man. Banneker replies with a supercilious smile.  15.
He’s our man now. The Scientists strides off. Vance shoots a troubled look Randall, and hurries after the Scientist.

Vance and Banneker soar into New Washington. They are alo the limousine pilots itself. New Washington is shining and beautiful: an architectural homage to the 20th-Century American city. Everywhere, signs of militarization: Soldiers on street corners. Propaganda posters. On billboards, military styl evident in civilian fashions. The red hawk banner of the Allied States flies from every building.
I haven't been here in years. It’s beautiful.
City population is forty-six million. Growth rate is five percent plus a year. It's unsustainable. Vance stares at Banneker in distaste.
I’ve been off-world for two years. It’s beautiful. The limousine settles in front of an imposing classical skyscraper: The headquarters of the State Science Agency.

The cavernous lobby bustles with people. They wear styliz lab coats in white, gray, or black. The youngest wear whi coats, the oldest black. Heavily armed Agency Guards stand post at every door. Banneker strides through the vast front doors, Vance in t

Welcome to the State Science Agency. Vance looks like he’s just stepped through the looking gl  16. Banneker heads for a distant bank of elevators. As they approach, he stares at an elevator: it opens.

The doors close. Vance and Banneker are alone. Banneker gazes intently at the elevator’s control panel. Lights flash to life, and the elevator descends. The floor indicator reaches the lowest basement level - b the elevator KEEPS SINKING.
We're still descending.
Yes. Vance stares. Banneker ignores him. The elevator plummets deep underground. After an endless time the elevator sighs to a halt. The d don’t open. Banneker hands Vance an electronic slate.
Before entering this facility, you must sign this writ of secrecy. Frowning, Vance scrolls through the dense legalese.
"Penalties for violation of secrecy may include revocation of citizenship, imprisonment, or execution." Execution?
You can easily avoid the penalties by obeying the writ. The men stare at each other. Finally Vance presses his thumbprint in the signature box. Banneker takes the slate The elevator doors open.

Vance and Banneker emerge into a bright vestibule. A cann on the ceiling rotates and aims its muzzle at Vance. Vance takes an experimental sidestep; the cannon ignores Banneker and tracks Vance like a hunting dog.  17.
Security’s tight down here.
Banneker and Vance walk abreast at a brisk clip.
Why do you think we selected you, out of a hundred thousand Marines? A Scientist in a grey coat walks by, shepherding a myster mechanism on a motorized cart. Vance watches it pass.
Selected me for what?
We'll get to that. Why you?
I’ve seen more action than most.
You've survived more missions than any trooper in the Offworld Corps. They pass another security cannon. Vance watches the weap unhappily as it tracks him.
I’ve been lucky.

You have the fastest reflexes in the Corps, and the lowest resting pulse rate. Your eyesight and hearing are in the first percentile. You’re an amazing specimen. But that’s all trivia. The point is, you're the man who comes home.
So far.

A huge subterranean space, gleaming and supermodern. Walk above walkways, all bustling with movement as Scientists hurry to and fro. In the center of the Concourse stands a great GLOBE OF EA it shows the world divided into two super-nations that co  18. every speck of land on the planet - the Allied States mar in red, the Hegemony in blue. Beside the globe stands JAROD MARBECK, 65, DIRECTOR OF TH STATE SCIENCE AGENCY. Magisterial and severe in an ornate black coat and cap.
Welcome, Captain. I'm Jarod Marbeck, Director of the State Science Agency. (he smiles) You're wondering why you're here.
Yeah. Marbeck points at the globe turning slowly above them.
We've lived in a state of cold war for more than a century. All our lives. Do you know how many times we've come close to total war?
No.
Six. Six times we've armed our doomsday weapons and teetered on the brink of extinction. Imagine that! Marbeck shakes his head with the air of a man personally offended.

We Scientists work to protect humanity. From disease. Famine. Cosmic accidents of every kind. This Agency has quietly rescued humanity more times than I can count. And for what? So our idiot politicians and military barbarians can march us right back to the abyss! The world's in danger. Our only home.
We have colonies on the outer planets.
Little steel bubbles filled with air! If Earth is lost, they'll (MORE )
DIRECTOR MARBECK (cont'd) perish in a year or two. No, I saw the truth long ago. There's only one way to safeguard our future.
What's that?
We need another world.

Marbeck and Banneker lead Vance into an immaculate white conference room. Around the table: SCIENTIST WALTER LARSON, 60, slender an folksy; SCIENTIST MARTIN CAUL, 70, a bearded man with fie eyes; and SCIENTIST CORDELIA RHAY, 65, keen and severe. All the Scientists wear black coats and skullcaps. Behind each Scientist stands a gray-coated Apprentice. Vance's eyes are drawn to Martin Caul's Apprentice: ADA KILDARE, 30, a beauty whose hair falls to her shoulders. watches Vance with open curiosity. Marbeck and Banneker sit, leaving a chair at the foot of table. After an awkward moment Vance takes the empty chai

Colleagues, this is Captain Conrad Vance of the Offworld Marine Corps. The Scientists inspect him. Vance looks back, his eyes lingering boldly on Ada. Flustered, she looks away. Marbeck points at Vance.

I was your age when I became Director. You see, I was a prodigy too: but where you excel at killing, I had other talents. I enlarged the Astronomy division and began a search of the heavens. And in just five years I found what I was looking for. He raises his hand, and a STAR swells into existence in t air above the conference table - which is also a holograp generator. Vance is startled, which amuses the Scientists
Erix. Similar in size and orbit to our own world, with a single large (MORE )

DIRECTOR MARBECK (cont'd) moon. A new hope for humanity, just twenty light-years away. IN HOLOGRAM: Planets spring into being around the star. T fourth planet, ERIX, grows to fill the space over the tab an angry red planet with a pale yellow moon.

I assembled the best scientific minds in the Agency. And they designed and built the most extraordinary spacecraft ever made. IN HOLOGRAM: The scene shifts. A spaceport orbits Jupiter Cradled in its scaffold is a saucer-shaped spacecraft. As the view shifts, the ship’s immensity becomes apparent Construction ships swarm over it like ants.
Prometheus!
(awed) Nothing’s that big. The elderly Scientist Larson grins.

Prometheus is. Half a kilometer across, with a mass of seventy million tons. And history's biggest gravity drive running through its core. It’s a magnificent monster. Marbeck indulges Larson with a smile of real affection.
And the greatest secret ever kept.
How many people aboard?
None. The Prometheus has no passenger compartments, no cockpit. It's a super-intelligent machine designed to transform Erix into a new Earth.
A terraforming ship.
Yes! The Prometheus Project. This is Scientist Walter Larson, Chief (MORE )
DIRECTOR MARBECK (cont'd) Engineer. He designed Prometheus forty years ago. Vance looks at Larson in surprise. Marbeck gestures at th other Scientists around the table.

Scientist Cordelia Rhay, Chief Physicist. Scientist Martin Caul, Chief Planetologist. You've met Scientist Banneker, Project Coordinator. I lead the project. And our work has begun in earnest. After a thirty year voyage, Prometheus has arrived. IN HOLOGRAM: Prometheus orbits Erix. It releases a shower probes that fall onto the planet: a swarm of satellites t swing into crisscrossing orbits. Prometheus lands and DIVIDES elaborately. Six sections cr away on giant treads, each a titanic machine in its own right. The core remains, a spire reaching into the sky.

The ship’s core forms the Prometheus Ground Station, here. Six crawlers spread over the surface, sowing the seeds of new life. And now to the point. One of these crawlers has broken down. (he points) Crawler Three. Its communications array has failed. Without satellite data it can no longer chart its course. It will not move or launch the rockets it carries.
How can you know this? It’s impossible to know what’s happening twenty light-years away. Any message would take twenty years to get here.

That’s true - in the physics you were taught. But there have been some unannounced breakthroughs in the field. The Prometheus is connected to Earth by a device called a Lang Transporter. It allows objects to “travel” instantaneously from one point to another. The Prometheus has been (MORE )
RHAY (cont'd) sending us progress reports roughly once a week.
You have a teleportation machine.
A Lang Transporter. Yes.
A transporter, Captain Vance, that works in both directions. A device large enough to transport a man. Vance digests this information. The Scientists watch him.
You want me to go to Erix.
Yes.
You want me to repair Crawler Three. Marbeck smiles like a teacher pleased with a clever stude

Marbeck leads Vance and the other Scientist along at a br clip. Security cannons continue to pick Vance out of the crowd and track him as he passes. Vance, shell-shocked by all he's learned, is trying to ge his head around it.
I thought I was pretty well- informed. You know, I read the news. Marbeck chuckles.
The events that truly shape the world rarely make the news. Especially in this day and age.

A cavern of staggering dimensions, its floor lost in shad far below. A futuristic reactor looms in the darkness. At center of its coils: a chamber not much bigger than a cof  23. A catwalk stretches across empty space to the chamber. Marbeck leads Vance out onto the bridge. His voice echoes

The Lang Transporter. The only device of its kind. Humanity’s greatest invention, if humanity only knew it. That doorway there, that chamber...a gateway to another world. You will be the first to pass through, Captain. The first.

A huge industrial space connected to the Transport Facili Heavy machines hulk in the corners. Massive cranes hang overhead. The floor is a mosaic of conveyor belts and mov platforms. Banneker leads Vance in.
We have everything you should need. If we don’t have it, we can probably get it. If we can’t get it we'll make it for you. Banneker points to a door at the top of a metal staircase

Your quarters. Close to the work. A klaxon sounds: a massive locker descends into the Stagi Room on an elevator. The crate is marked with Marine insi and Vance’s name. Banneker gazes at a heavy crane: it leaps into motion. Li the locker from the elevator. Sets it down and withdraws.
You keep doing that.
Doing what?
Controlling machines with your eyes. Elevators, doors, the crane. How's it work?
In the Agency, rank has its privileges.  24. He removes his cap. He is bald: a sleek metal crown cling his scalp. Its terminals pass through the skin into his h
Ouch.

When there are secrets to be kept, machines make the best servants. We don’t need many human helpers here. Vance keys his ID code into the massive locker. Thumbs th print reader. The case opens. Inside: Vance’s armor - and an arsenal of weapons and too Banneker peers into the locker. Inspects a rack of someth like wet-suits. He fingers one curiously. It's marked wit Vance's name and Captain's rank insignia.
What is this?
Skinsuit. You wear it under the armor. Soaks up sweat, keeps your skin clean, heals wounds. It even scratches where you itch. Best of all, on a long mission it catheterizes you.
Ouch.
Yeah. You tend to have a love-hate relationship with your skinsuit.
Vance, wearing a skinsuit, stands in front of his armor.
Athena, wake up. Athena’s electronic voice speaks from the battle suit. ATHENA’S VOICE Captain Vance.

Open.  25. The battle-suit SPLITS OPEN like some strange mollusk - t helmet swings back, the body opens wide. Vance slips easily into the armor, and it closes around h He stands up wearing half a ton of metal.
Offworld Marine, ready for duty.
Very impressive. Come and see the repair job. We have a mock-up.

Hang on. Vance reaches into the locker and clamps a bulky apparatu onto his left forearm. He points it at Banneker. Its muzzle belches a blur of motion that makes Banneker flinch violently - but it’s only a rapid rotation of tool socket-wrench, chisel, hammer, pincers.

(grinning) Field engineer’s toolkit. Can’t hurt you. Behind Vance, unknown to him, the Staging Room machines t on him: the heavy crane hangs overhead, its quivering jaw ready to crush him. A pit opens at his heels. Security cannons awaken and take aim. Banneker relaxes, and the machines withdraw silently into shadows.

Vance, in full armor, enters on Banneker’s heels. Apprent gape at the giant in their midst. A house-sized machine dominates the room. It’s shaped lik beetle’s head: two eye-like domes, a shell of armor plate One armored dome is torn raggedly open.
This is a replica of Crawler Three’s comm array. We reproduced the damage from diagnostics. Vance takes in the complex machine. Shoots Banneker a loo  26.
Look, why am I here? You've got to have hundreds of engineers who could do this.

The Offworld Marine battle suit is the toughest spacesuit there is. And it takes months of training to wear it. A skilled Marine was our best option. Vance walks up the module’s hull and inspects the damage. casually peels back the thick metal and peers inside. Banneker’s eyes widen at this feat of strength.
What did this?
Unknown. Probably collision damage. Erix isn’t flat.
It's not pretty. But it looks like the only real damage is this cable. It's an easy fix.
(skeptically) There are components you have to move. Systems to shut down and restart in a certain order.
Easy. Good.

Scientist Larson’s kingdom, a gallery of technical diagra and intricate mechanisms. Larson, Banneker, and Vance survey a huge scale model of Prometheus and its Crawlers. They cluster around the model of Crawler Three.

Now when you complete this repair, watch out. Crawler Three’s going to start talking to Prometheus, and in less than a second they’1l exchange more information than a human brain handles in a lifetime. Crawler (MORE )

SCIENTIST LARSON (cont'd) Three’s going to find out it's late starting the Ocean Program. And right that second it'll launch its rockets, bound for the seas of Erix. Larson frowns. Four hatch-covers flip open on top of the model of Crawler Three. Four model rockets emerge. Larson lifts one with obvious pleasure.
Big rockets. It’ll get hot for you. Around two thousand degrees Kelvin.
For how long?
Ten seconds or so. Only a second or two of peak heat.
All right. I can ride that out.
(grins) That’s a damned fancy suit.
(returning the smile) Yes, sir. What do these rockets do?
The oceans are the foundation of the biosphere. The rockets are loaded with bacteria designed to change...
